msItem.explicit: nisi vobis aliud forte congruentius uideatur

msItem.incipit: Prima igitur questio circa regulam nostram uersatur
msItem.explicit: nam ego siue in paucis siue in multis uestre debui satisfacere uoluntati. Explicit.

msItem.incipit: In hoc opusculo cum illud de euangelio quod dominus ait
msItem.explicit: Quam tamen in fine opusculi ipse breuiter intimare curaui

msItem.incipit: Pogasti Rogasti me frater Gotefride. quantinus ea que de gradibus humilitatis coram fratribus locutus fueram

supportDesc.collation: 1(two) (fols. 2–3, presumably the last two leaves of a quire of eight), 2(8)-20(8) (fols. 4–155). Leaf signature (?), fol. 23r.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet for 28 lines, written above top line; the capitula on fol. 123r–v in two columns. Ruled space 170 105

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials in plain red, some with elaborate arabesque/silhouette embellishment (e.g fols. 2v, 10v, 21r)

binding.p:
Laudian binding. Sewn in four double alum-tawed(?) bands laced into pasteboards covered with tanned brown leather, each framed with blind fillets and with the gilt arms of Archbishop Laud in the centre. The edges of the leaves gilt. Traces of two ties. The spine with an old paper label inscribed ‘Bernardus
de Considerac
ione &c
M’ and ‘B’, and two Bodleian printed paper labels.

history.provenance: ‘Liber S. Johnson’ and ‘S. Bernardi quædam.’, early 17th cent. (fol. 1r): Samson Johnson, a protege of William Laud, preacher (concionator) attached to Sir Robert Anstruther, British ambassador at the Diet of Frankfurt-am-Main (see the Quarto Catalogue, p. xx).
history.acquisition: Part of his first donation to the Bodleian, sent 22 May 1635. Former Bodleian shelfmarks: ‘J.9.’ and ‘Laud 355’ (front pastedown).

recordHist.source: Summary description (March 2021) by Peter Kidd, edited with dimensions and collation supplied by Matthew Holford. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (H. O. Coxe, Laudian Manuscripts, Quarto Catalogues II, repr. with corrections, 1969, from the original ed. of 1858–1885).
